questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

 

  • Patient with sudden-onset severe chest pain, with a difference in blood pressure between the two limbs, and a widened mediastinum on x-ray suggests a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
  • AORTIC DISSECTION is tear in intima of aorta

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): ACS includes conditions such as myocardial infarction and unstable angina. These conditions typically present with chest pain but do not usually cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and signs of right heart strain. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option D. Esophageal Rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and signs of sepsis. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. It may cause mediastinal widening but would more likely present with other signs such as subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

 

The combination of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain resulting from arthritis, and urinary findings of hematuria and proteinuria is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and renal abnormalities. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years.

 

The patient may present with the following clinical features:

 

  • Skin lesions- These typically involve the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs, as well as the buttocks.
  • Pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding are examples of abdominal manifestations.
  • Renal manifestations include hematuria, nephritic syndrome, and nephrotic syndrome. Adults have more severe renal manifestations. Some patients develop a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura: typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding, without joint pain or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Dengue fever: Dengue fever is a viral illness that typically presents with fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Churg-Strauss syndrome is a rare systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis, often involving multiple organs. While arthritis may be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, palpable purpura is uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schonlein purpura is characterized by the presence of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement, typically manifesting as hematuria and proteinuria. It is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly affecting children and is distinguished by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in affected tissues.

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months. What is the next best investigation to do? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) UPT

 

Explanation:

 

In a 28-year-old woman with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months, the first step is to rule out pregnancy. The initial investigation in this scenario should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT). This is crucial because pregnancy-related complications such as threatened abortion, incomplete abortion, or ectopic pregnancy can present with irregular bleeding. Identifying or excluding pregnancy is the most immediate concern and guides subsequent management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound): This is a valuable tool for assessing pelvic pathology and uterine abnormalities, but it is typically done after confirming the UPT results.

 

Option C. Pap smear: This test is used for cervical cancer screening and is not the immediate next step in evaluating irregular bleeding when pregnancy needs to be ruled out first.

 

Option D. USG abdomen: While an abdominal ultrasound can provide useful information, it is less sensitive than a transvaginal ultrasound for early pregnancy detection and pelvic pathology assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a reproductive-age woman with irregular bleeding, the first investigation should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT) to rule out pregnancy-related causes.

choices.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

 

Explanation

 

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.

 

Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:

 

  1. Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  2. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  3. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  4.  Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.

 

Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.

 

Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

 

In osteoporosis, there is an imbalance between bone resorption (breakdown) and bone formation, with resorption exceeding formation. This leads to bone weakening, which is why the patient has a pathological fracture.

 

The key markers that are elevated in cases of osteoporosis include N & C terminal telopeptides and tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), which are markers of increased bone resorption. In osteoporosis, TRAP levels are elevated, indicating that bone destruction is occurring at a higher rate than formation.

 

Other markers like ALP (alkaline phosphatase) may also be raised, but the specific marker for bone resorption and the correct answer in this case is TRAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine Transaminase: This is a liver enzyme commonly elevated in liver diseases, but it has no direct association with bone metabolism or osteoporosis.

 

Option B. Aspartate Aminotransferase: Like ALT, AST is another liver enzyme, primarily elevated in liver damage and certain heart conditions. It is unrelated to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Option C. Lactate Dehydrogenase: LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues and may be elevated in conditions involving tissue breakdown, but it is not specific to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.

questions.text: Accidental death occurred in a man 3 days after the accident. During the postmortem examination, bleeding was observed in the head that was not washed away by water. This can be due to: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid bleeding

 

In postmortem examinations, different types of intracranial hemorrhages can be observed. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is characterized by bleeding that occurs between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater. This type of bleeding is protected by the arachnoid mater, making it resistant to being washed away by water during an autopsy. The presence of persistent bleeding after washing indicates that it is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Note – EDH Vs SDH Vs SAH

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural bleeding: Epidural hemorrhage (EDH) occurs between the dura mater and the skull. It is typically easy to identify and does not remain after washing.

 

Option C. SDH: Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. This type of bleeding usually washes away with water during an autopsy.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal bleeding: Intraparenchymal bleeding occurs within the brain tissue itself. While it may not wash away completely, the described scenario specifically matches the characteristics of subarachnoid bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is identified by the persistence of bleeding in the head that is not washed away by water during an autopsy, due to its protection by the arachnoid mater

questions.text: A patient with dyspnea, respiratory distress due to pan-acinar emphysema, and liver dysfunction is due to a likely defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency

 

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency of the alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein, which protects the lungs from neutrophil elastase.

 

This deficiency leads to the development of pan-acinar emphysema, especially in the lower lobes of the lungs, and liver dysfunction, such as cirrhosis, due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha 1 anti-trypsin in hepatocytes.

 

The combination of pulmonary and hepatic manifestations, particularly pan-acinar emphysema, is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A gene: Mutations in this gene are associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism, leading to systemic copper deficiency. It does not cause emphysema or liver dysfunction seen in alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency.

 

Option B. ATP7B gene: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, which affects copper metabolism, leading to liver disease and neurological symptoms but not emphysema.

 

Option D. Surfactant defect: Surfactant deficiency typically occurs in preterm infants, leading to respiratory distress syndrome due to immature lung development. It does not cause emphysema or liver dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is associated with pan-acinar emphysema and liver dysfunction due to a deficiency of the protective alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

The most likely organism based on the given history and image is Trichophyton rubrum. The colonies appear velvety and a deep red, non-diffusible pigment is seen when viewed from the reverse side of the colony. A few long and pencil-shaped macroconidia can be seen.

 

Trichophyton is a dermatophytic fungi that can infect hair, skin, or nails. Dermatophytes infect only the keratinized tissue and have keratinases that can digest keratin. There are 3 genera of dermatophytes:

 

  • ﻿﻿Trichophyton - The colonies may appear powdery, waxy, or velvety with pigmentation characteristics of different species.
  • ﻿﻿Epidermophyton - It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair. The colonies appear powdery and greenish-yellow.
  • Microsporum - It infects the hair and skin, but not the nails. The colonies may appear cotton-like, velvety, or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation.

 

Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea corporis. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum, with lesions on the trunk and limbs. The lesions are usually well-defined and circular with a raised edge. It can also cause tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colonies of Trichophyton violaceus are very slow-growing, waxy with a violet/purple pigment. They have distorted hyphae, with conidia seen rarely.

 

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans has a cream or yellowish colony with central furrows. Microconidia are abundantly seen. Thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are also seen.

 

 

Option D. Colonies of Trichophyton schoenleinii are smooth, waxy and brownish. Hyphal swellings are seen along with chlamydospores and favic chandelier.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: In a case of RTA (Road Traffic Accident), a person has died. Who can order an autopsy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Police Officer


In cases of deaths such as those resulting from road traffic accidents, the decision to conduct an autopsy is made by the Investigating Officer (IO), typically a Police Officer. The Police Officer is responsible for the inquest, which involves examining the circumstances of the death and deciding whether an autopsy is necessary to determine the cause of death. While the actual conduction of the autopsy is performed by a forensic doctor, the authorization comes from the Police Officer handling the case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Public Prosecutor: The Public Prosecutor is involved in legal proceedings but does not have the authority to order an autopsy. Their role begins after the investigation and autopsy have been conducted and evidence is gathered.

 

Option B. Defendant Lawyer: The Defendant Lawyer represents the accused in legal proceedings and has no authority to order an autopsy. Their role is strictly legal defense, not investigative.

 

Option D. Forensic Medicine Doctor: The Forensic Medicine Doctor conducts the autopsy but does not have the authority to order one. They act upon the request of the Investigating Officer who is in charge of the case.

 

Educational Objective:


The Police Officer, specifically the Investigating Officer, has the authority to order an autopsy in cases of unexplained or suspicious deaths, such as those resulting from a road traffic accident.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

 

  • This is an echocardiogram that is performed while the heart is under the stress of increased workload. If a patient cannot exercise, a drug called dobutamine is administered to simulate the effects of exercise on the heart.
  • The test helps identify areas of the heart that may not be receiving enough blood due to blockages in the coronary arteries. A significant change in the motion of the heart wall during the test is a strong predictor of perioperative cardiac complications, making this test highly valuable in the mentioned context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exercise ECG testing: Exercise ECG testing, also known as exercise stress testing or treadmill testing, involves the patient exercising on a treadmill or stationary bicycle while their heart rate, blood pressure, and electrocardiogram (ECG) are monitored. The purpose is to determine how the heart responds to the stress of exercise. Abnormal changes in the ECG during or after exercise may suggest coronary artery disease (CAD). While this test can indicate the presence of CAD, it does not specifically predict perioperative cardiac complications.

 

Option C. Myocardial perfusion scintigraphy: Also known as a nuclear stress test, this investigation involves injecting a small amount of radioactive substance into the patient and using a special camera to visualize how blood flows through the heart muscle, both at rest and during stress (either exercise or with a medication). This test can identify areas of the heart that aren't getting enough blood, indicative of CAD. While it can detect and evaluate the severity of CAD, it's less specific than dobutamine stress echocardiography in predicting perioperative cardiac complications.

 

Option D. Coronary angiography: This is a procedure in which a contrast dye is injected into the coronary arteries, and X-rays are taken to visualize the flow of blood through these arteries. It is used to directly visualize blockages in the coronary arteries. As the "gold standard" for diagnosing CAD, coronary angiography can provide detailed information about the location and severity of blockages. However, it's an invasive procedure, involving threading a catheter through the blood vessels to the heart, and carries risks such as bleeding, allergic reactions, or kidney damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dobutamine stress echocardiography is the most accurate non-invasive investigation for predicting perioperative cardiac complications due to its ability to simulate exercise and identify areas of the heart with reduced blood flow.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 935

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single dose methotrexate

 

Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy can include expectant, medical, or surgical approaches depending on the patient's condition and specific characteristics of the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Medical Management (Single Dose Methotrexate):

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis, effectively treating ectopic pregnancies by stopping the growth of the trophoblastic tissue.
  • Indications for Methotrexate:
    • Patient hemodynamically stable.
    • No significant symptoms.
    • Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm.
    • No visible cardiac activity.
    • Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L.
    • No contraindication to Methotrexate.

 

In this scenario, the patient has a beta hCG level of 2800 mIU/mL, a 3 cm mass in the left adnexa, and no fetal cardiac activity, making her an appropriate candidate for single-dose methotrexate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management:

 

  • Indications:
    • Clinically stable with no pain.
    • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L.
    • Tubal ectopic < 35 mm with no visible heartbeat.
    • Ability to return for follow-up.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's beta hCG level is 2800 mIU/mL and she presents with symptoms, thus expectant management is not suitable.

 

Option C. Salpingectomy:

 

  • Indications:
    • Significant pain.
    • Adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger.
    • Visible fetal heartbeat on ultrasound.
    • Serum hCG level of 5000 IU/L or more.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's ectopic pregnancy size and beta hCG levels do not meet the criteria for surgical intervention. She is hemodynamically stable and a good candidate for medical management.

 

Option D. Milking of the tube:

 

  • Indications: Generally not a recommended procedure due to the risk of incomplete removal of trophoblastic tissue and subsequent complications.
  • Reason for not choosing: This option is outdated and not typically recommended for the management of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.

 

Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: Tracheal innermost layer has which epithelial lining? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified columnar epithelium

 

The trachea, or windpipe, is lined with a specific type of epithelium designed to protect and facilitate the movement of mucus. The innermost layer of the trachea consists of pseudostratified columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium appears to have multiple layers (strata) because the cells' nuclei are at different levels, giving a false impression of stratification (hence "pseudo"). However, it is actually a single layer of cells.

 

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium primarily consists of tall, column-like cells that are closely packed together. Despite appearing layered due to the varying positions of the nuclei, it is a single layer of cells. This structure is crucial for the trachea as it often contains cilia (tiny hair-like projections) and goblet cells that produce mucus. The cilia help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, aiding in keeping the airways clear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous epithelium: This type of epithelium consists of flat, thin cells and is usually found in areas where rapid diffusion or filtration is required, such as the alveoli in the lungs. It is not suitable for the trachea, which needs a more robust lining to handle mucus and cilia.

 

Option B. Ciliary epithelium: While the pseudostratified columnar epithelium in the trachea does contain ciliated cells, "ciliary epithelium" itself is not a distinct classification of epithelial tissue. Therefore, this option is incorrect as a type of epithelial lining.

 

Option D. Cuboidal epithelium: This type of epithelium consists of cube-shaped cells and is generally found in glandular tissues or ducts (like kidney tubules). It is not found lining the trachea, as it lacks the specialized structure needed for mucus movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The innermost layer of the trachea is lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium, which appears layered due to the positioning of cell nuclei but is actually a single layer of cells designed to protect the respiratory tract and facilitate mucus movement.

questions.text: A firefighter with a history of smoke inhalation presents with fever, cough, and signs of lung consolidation. Sputum culture reveals colonies with a green pigment and fluorescence under UV light. Which organism is most likely? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

The key diagnostic features here are the green pigment (pyocyanin) and fluorescence under UV light, which are characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pyocyanin is a diffusible pigment that gives colonies their distinctive green color. The history of smoke inhalation is also relevant as P. aeruginosa commonly causes opportunistic infections in damaged airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae produces alpha-hemolytic colonies without pigment or fluorescence

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Klebsiella pneumoniae produces mucoid colonies without pigment or fluorescence

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus produces golden-yellow colonies without fluorescence

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa's characteristic laboratory features: green pigment (pyocyanin) production and fluorescence under UV light, particularly in the context of respiratory infections following airway damage.

questions.text: A tumor marker analysis shows elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in a patient. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with increased AFP? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a tumor marker that is most strongly associated with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). AFP is a glycoprotein normally produced during fetal development by the yolk sac and fetal liver. After birth, AFP levels decrease rapidly and remain low throughout adult life. In HCC, malignant hepatocytes revert to a more primitive state and resume AFP production, leading to elevated serum levels. AFP is considered one of the most important diagnostic and monitoring markers for HCC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seminoma: Incorrect. Pure seminomas typically do not produce AFP. AFP elevation in testicular tumors is characteristic of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs) like yolk sac tumors and embryonal carcinomas. The presence of elevated AFP in a patient with testicular cancer would rule out pure seminoma.

 

Option B. Hepatic adenoma: Incorrect. Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors that generally do not produce AFP. While there might be mild elevations in some cases, significant AFP elevation is not characteristic of hepatic adenomas.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Incorrect. Bronchogenic carcinoma is not typically associated with elevated AFP levels. The tumor markers more commonly associated with lung cancer include CEA, CYFRA 21-1, NSE (for small cell carcinoma), and ProGRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common malignancy associated with significantly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels, making AFP an important diagnostic and monitoring marker for this cancer.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to bowing of the legs. On examination, the child has widening of the wrists and frontal bossing. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

Bowing of the legs in a 2-year-old child is most commonly associated with rickets, a condition caused by vitamin D deficiency leading to defective bone mineralization​

 

Features of Rickets:

 

  • Bowing of legs (genu varum) in toddlers
  • Widening of wrists
  • Delayed fontanelle closure
  • Frontal bossing
  • Rachitic rosary (prominent costochondral junctions)
  • Harrison sulcus (groove in the lower rib cage due to diaphragmatic pull)
  • Growth retardation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Caused by vitamin C deficiency, presenting with bleeding gums, corkscrew hairs, and perifollicular hemorrhages, but not bowing of legs.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Congenital syphilis can cause saber shins (anterior bowing of tibia), but it is less common and usually presents with other stigmata like Hutchinson’s teeth and saddle nose deformity.

 

Option D. Anemia: Does not cause bowing of the legs. Iron-deficiency anemia may cause fatigue and pallor but does not affect bone structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickets should be suspected in children with bowing of the legs, delayed fontanelle closure, and widened wrists. It is caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to defective bone mineralization.

questions.text: Female on maize as a staple diet. History of diarrhea and lesion in the neck region. It is due to deficiency of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

This is a typical picture of Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency causing pellagra. Pellagra is characterized by 4Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dermatitis (Casal’s Necklace) dementia and Death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc Deficiency is characterized by acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.), diarrhea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pellagra

 

  1. Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion.
  2. Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis.
  3. Malabsorption
  4. Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

questions.text: Which tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus on inversion of the foot? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior tibialis

 

The posterior tibialis tendon is located behind the medial malleolus, and it is palpable when the foot is inverted. This tendon is essential for supporting the arch of the foot and plays a significant role in foot inversion. During the movement of foot inversion, the posterior tibialis tendon becomes more prominent and easier to palpate behind the medial malleolus, which is the bony prominence on the inner side of the ankle.

 

The posterior tibialis tendon inserts on the navicular bone (sometimes referred to as the scaphoid of the foot). This tendon’s attachment helps maintain the foot's arch and aids in foot inversion.

 

Note - Kohler disease is a rare bone disorder that causes osteochondritis of the navicular bone in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibialis: The anterior tibialis tendon is located on the anterior side of the ankle and foot. It is responsible for dorsiflexion (lifting the foot upward) and does not pass behind the medial malleolus, making it unpalpable in this area during inversion.

 

Option B. Extensor hallucis brevis: The extensor hallucis brevis is involved in extending the big toe. It does not run behind the medial malleolus and is located on the dorsum of the foot, so it is unrelated to the action of inversion or palpation behind the medial malleolus.

 

Option C. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon extends the big toe and assists in dorsiflexion of the foot. It is found on the anterior aspect of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and is not palpable during inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot and inserts on the navicular bone.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.

 

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. malariae: Causes quartan malaria with a longer incubation period and typically presents with band-form trophozoites across the red cells, distinct from the forms seen in P. falciparum.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Known for causing tertian malaria with similar clinical presentations to P. vivax, including the presence of Schüffner's dots and slightly enlarged and ovale-shaped erythrocytes.

 

Option D. P. vivax: Also causes tertian malaria, characterized by Schüffner's stippling in erythrocytes, larger ring forms than P. falciparum, and less severe disease outcomes compared to P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identification of P. falciparum through the presence of distinctive ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral smear is crucial for rapid initiation of appropriate antimalarial therapy, particularly in endemic regions. Early treatment is vital to prevent severe complications and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

H/O consumption of a fruit, high fever, confusion, photophobia, unable to urinate are anticholinergic symptoms. Photophobia occurs due to mydriasis in anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.

 

Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.

 

Features of Datura poisoning:

 

 D's of Datura

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death

 

Datura Flowers: Flowers are large tubular (trumpet-shaped) which may be white (alba) or purple (Niger)

 

Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains 50 to 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which bear a superficial resemblance to chilly seeds

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning: Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug, physostigmine [Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity]

 

Below image shows Datura Flower and Datura Fruit

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. While Datura is the correct causative agent, Pralidoxime is not the correct antidote. Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. Yellow oleander poisoning presents primarily with symptoms of cardiac toxicity, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, not the anticholinergic symptoms described in the question. Additionally, Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect. Again, Yellow oleander would cause symptoms related to cardiac toxicity rather than the anticholinergic symptoms presented. Physostigmine is not the antidote for Yellow oleander poisoning.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • Types:
  1. Nerium odorum (White Oleander): Bears white, dark red or pink flowers
  2. Cerbera thevetia (Yellow Oleander): Bears yellow bell-shaped flowers, globular fruits

 

 

  • Symptoms: In both oleanders there will symptoms of heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse) and muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. They are similar to digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine is useful in the management of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and bigeminy.
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies (digoxin-specific Fab fragments) are the treatment of choice for severe bradyarrhythmia’s with hypotension unresponsive to atropine and life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias.

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with hearing loss. On PTA, the amount of hearing loss was 56dB: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

 

Otosclerosis is a common cause of progressive hearing loss, particularly in young adults and often worsens during pregnancy due to hormonal changes. The condition is characterized by abnormal bone growth around the stapes bone in the middle ear, leading to its fixation. This fixation prevents the stapes from vibrating in response to sound waves, thereby reducing the transmission of sound to the inner ear and causing hearing loss.

 

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane (eardrum) typically appears normal upon examination. The hearing loss in otosclerosis is conductive, meaning it is due to a problem in the outer or middle ear, which transmits sound to the inner ear. A pure-tone audiogram (PTA) showing a 56dB hearing loss indicates significant conductive hearing impairment, consistent with otosclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane: This condition is not typical of otosclerosis. Ossicular fixation in otosclerosis occurs with an intact tympanic membrane. A non-intact tympanic membrane would suggest a different pathology, such as chronic otitis media.

 

Option C. Erosion with intact tympanic membrane: Ossicular erosion with an intact tympanic membrane is not characteristic of otosclerosis. Ossicular erosion is more commonly seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), particularly in its cholesteatoma form, which can erode the ossicles but usually involves perforation of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Erosion without intact tympanic membrane: This is also not typical of otosclerosis. Erosion without an intact tympanic membrane again points towards chronic otitis media, especially with complications leading to ossicular erosion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otosclerosis often presents as progressive conductive hearing loss with an intact tympanic membrane, and the hearing loss can worsen during pregnancy. The classic finding is ossicular fixation, particularly of the stapes bone.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

 

  • Image given is of trophic ulcer, typically seen in diabetic patients because of lack of sensation.
  • They are seen on weight bearing parts of foot.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: A patient presented with features as given in the image below.What is the likely  diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Arsenic

 

The image shows characteristic features of arsenic poisoning, including Mees' lines (Aldrich Mees lines) on the nails, which are transverse white lines seen in cases of heavy metal poisoning, particularly arsenic and thallium. The skin findings, such as hyperpigmentation and "raindrop" appearance, are also commonly associated with chronic arsenic exposure. Even though thallium poisoning can also present with similar nail changes, arsenic is the best answer unless alopecia is specifically noted, which is more common in thallium poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as tremors, psychological disturbances, and gingivitis, not with the distinct Mees' lines and skin changes seen here.

 

Option C. Lead: Lead poisoning commonly affects the nervous system and presents with symptoms like abdominal pain, constipation, and lead lines on the gums (Burton’s lines), not the nail and skin changes shown in the image.

 

Option D. Copper: Copper toxicity, such as Wilson's disease, typically presents with liver, neurological symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes, not with Mees' lines or the described skin pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mees' lines and raindrop pigmentation of the skin are classic signs of arsenic poisoning. In the absence of alopecia, arsenic is the preferred diagnosis over thallium.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homogentisate oxidase

 

Option A. Homogentisate oxidase: This is the correct enzyme.

 

Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase, which leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body. This acid can darken upon exposure to air, resulting in blackened urine and other symptoms.

 

It is compatible with fairly normal life. The only abnormality is the blackening of urine on standing. The homogentisic acid is oxidized by polyphenol oxidase to benzoquinone acetate. It is then polymerized to black colored alkaptone bodies.

 

By the 3rd or 4th decade of life, patient may develop ochronosis (deposition of alkaptone bodies in intervertebral discs, cartilages of nose, pinna of ear). Black pigments are deposited over the connective tissues including joint cavities to produce arthritis.

 

Diagnosis of Alkaptonuria:

 

  1. Urine becomes black on standing when it becomes alkaline. Blackening is accelerated on exposure to sunlight and oxygen. The urine when kept in a test tube will start to blacken from the top layer.
  2. Ferric chloride test will be positive for urine.
  3. Benedict’s test is strongly positive. Due to reducing nature of homogentisic acid in urine.

 

Treatment: No specific treatment is required. But minimal protein intake with phenylalanine less than 500 mg/day is recommended.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Xanthine oxidase: Xanthine oxidase is not associated with Alkaptonuria. It is involved in the metabolism of purines, not in the pathway related to this condition.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), a different metabolic disorder causing mousy/musty body odor.

 

Option D. Dihydro orotate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the pyrimidine biosynthesis pathway and is not related to Alkaptonuria.

 

Educational objective:

 

The diagnosis is alkaptonuria in which urine becomes black on standing due to oxidation of homogentisic acid present in the urine. The disease is autosomal recessive inherited and it is due to the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase/dioxygenase required for further metabolism of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoma Esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of an elderly female presenting with symptoms such as progressive dysphagia, loss of appetite and weight loss along with the given barium study which shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins. These findings are suggestive of Carcinoma Esophagus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Is a motility disorder of esophagus and appears as a corkscrew esophagus.

 

Option B. Esophageal leiomyoma: Is a benign neoplasm of the esophagus and on barium swallow it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass well outlined by barium.

 

Option D. Esophageal webs: Refers to an esophageal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient presenting with progressive dysphagia for solids and significant weight loss, the presence of irregular narrowing and shouldered margins on a barium swallow is highly suggestive of esophageal carcinoma. Diagnostic confirmation typically requires upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) and biopsy. For tumor staging, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is used for T and N staging, while PET-CT is utilized for M staging.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the ER with a history of trauma two weeks back with confusion and ataxia. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural haemorrhage

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).
  • Subdural hematomas typically occur due to the rupture of bridging veins, which can be associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, or chronic alcohol overuse.
  •  The presentation of symptoms like confusion and ataxia two weeks after trauma is characteristic of a chronic subdural hematoma.

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of bridging veins.
  • Etiology: Can be acute (traumatic) or chronic (associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, chronic alcohol overuse). Also seen in shaken babies.
  • Clinical Features: Typically presents without a lucid interval; altered consciousness from the onset. Features of raised intracranial tension and neurological deficits may be present.
  • CT Findings: Crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery), often secondary to a skull fracture involving the pterion.
  • Clinical Features: Often includes a lucid interval (period of normalcy between two periods of unconsciousness).
  • CT Findings: Biconvex (lentiform), hyperdense blood collection that does not cross suture lines.

 

Option C. Intra-parenchymal Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Most commonly caused by systemic hypertension.
  • Location: Most often occurs in the putamen/globus pallidus of the basal ganglia (lenticulostriate vessels).
  • CT Findings: Intra-parenchymal bleed.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Bleeding due to trauma or rupture of an aneurysm (such as a saccular aneurysm).
  • Clinical Features: Patients complain of the “worst headache of my life.” Bloody or yellow lumbar puncture. Vasospasm can occur, nimodipine is used to prevent/reduce it.
  • CT Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities represent acute hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval.
  •  CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

 

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal injury is commonly seen in total thyroidectomy.

 

  • Injury to both RLNs results in paralysis of intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The vocal cords cannot be abducted and thus come to lie in a median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid. This results in compromised laryngeal airway causing respiratory distress and stridor.
  • Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure to secure the airway.
  • Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:
    1. Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
    2. Partial arytenoidectomy
    3. Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
    4.  Thyroplasty type II – lateralisation of vocal cords

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury - This would primarily affect voice pitch and not typically cause significant breathing difficulty.

 

Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury - Would lead to hoarseness but not usually severe breathing issues as one vocal cord would still function.

 

Option D. Hematoma - Although it can cause acute respiratory distress if it compresses the trachea, it does not typically lead to issues with extubation unless it is very severe.

 

Educational Objective:


Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 339

questions.text: Rice water diarrhoea, intoxication is due to which ganglioside?(NEET PG  2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM-1 ganglioside receptor.

 

Explanation:

 

Rice water diarrhea is a characteristic symptom of cholera, which is caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae is the cholera toxin.

 

The cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. This binding leads to the activation of adenylate cyclase, increased levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP), and subsequent secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic rice water diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM-2 ganglioside receptor: GM-2 ganglioside is not related to cholera toxin binding. Instead, it is involved in diseases like Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff disease, where there is a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase, leading to the accumulation of GM-2 ganglioside.

 

Option C. GM-3 ganglioside receptor: GM-3 ganglioside is not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin. It is a simpler ganglioside involved in different cellular processes but not specifically in the pathology of cholera.

 

Option D. GD-1a ganglioside receptor: GD-1a ganglioside is not associated with the cholera toxin. It has roles in neural cell function and development but does not play a part in the mechanism of action of cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:


Cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on intestinal epithelial cells, causing the characteristic rice water diarrhea by increasing cyclic AMP levels and promoting water and electrolyte secretion into the intestinal lumen.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 202

questions.text: An adolescent male came with complaints of lesions all over the face and back, which were predominantly comedones. What is the most effective treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systemic doxycycline

 

Acne vulgaris, particularly when it predominantly presents with comedones, is a common condition in adolescents. Comedones are the primary lesions in acne, which can progress to inflammatory lesions if not adequately managed. Systemic doxycycline is an effective treatment for moderate to severe acne, particularly when it involves both comedones and inflammatory lesions like papules and pustules. Doxycycline acts as an antibacterial and anti-inflammatory agent, which helps reduce the bacteria responsible for acne (Propionibacterium acnes) and the inflammation associated with acne lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Systemic isotretinoin: Isotretinoin is a powerful systemic retinoid used primarily for severe, nodular cystic acne. Since the question specifies comedones without mention of nodulocystic lesions, systemic isotretinoin is not the most appropriate first-line treatment for this case.

 

Option C. Topical Dapsone: Topical Dapsone is used in the treatment of acne, particularly in inflammatory lesions. However, it may not be as effective for widespread comedones over the face and back, and topical treatments may not be feasible for extensive cases.

 

Option D. Systemic Azithromycin: While azithromycin is an antibiotic that can be used in acne treatment, it is less commonly used compared to doxycycline and is not the first-line treatment for comedonal acne. Doxycycline is preferred due to its broader use and efficacy in managing both comedonal and inflammatory acne lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic doxycycline is the most effective treatment for moderate to severe acne that involves comedones and inflammatory lesions, particularly when the condition is extensive.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia. On further evaluation, homonymous hemianopia and episodes of epilepsy were observed. A CT scan of the brain was performed What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal abscess

 

Explanation: 


The presentation indicates temporal lobe abscess because:

 

  • Clear space-occupying lesion in temporal lobe visible on CT
  • Classic symptoms of temporal lobe involvement: 
    • Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement
    • Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression
    • Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia)
  • Common complication of CSOM due to: 
    • Direct extension through tegmen tympani

    • Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM

       

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Meningitis

 

  • Most common intracranial complication of CSOM
  • No discrete abscess formation on imaging
  • Shows meningeal enhancement
  • Different clinical features (neck rigidity, Kernig's sign)

 

Option C. Subdural abscess

 

  • Collection between dura and arachnoid
  • Different imaging appearance
  • No discrete parenchymal involvement
  • Different clinical presentation

 

Option D. Extradural abscess

 

  • Collection outside dura but intracranial
  • Different imaging appearance
  • Less severe neurological symptoms
  • No parenchymal involvement

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of CSOM, presenting with seizures and characteristic CT findings of a space-occupying lesion in the temporal lobe.

choices.text: Transferrin saturation
RBC protoporphyrin
Total iron binding capacity
Serum transferrin receptors

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia all of the following is increased except? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transferrin saturation

 

Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin (the protein that transports iron in the blood) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the transferrin saturation is decreased because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

It is important to note that in a patient with iron deficiency anemia, there is increased TIBC as well as increased RBC Protoporphyrin levels and the number of serum transferrin receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC protoporphyrin: This is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway. In iron deficiency anemia, the lack of iron means that protoporphyrin accumulates, as it cannot be converted into heme. Therefore, RBC protoporphyrin levels are increased.

 

Option C. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): This is a measure of the total capacity of the blood to bind iron with transferrin. In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased as the body produces more transferrin in an attempt to capture more iron from the diet and the body’s stores.

 

Option D. Serum transferrin receptors: These receptors are present on the surface of cells and are involved in the uptake of transferrin-bound iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the number of these receptors increases as the body tries to increase iron uptake from the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

 

The identification of Trichophyton mentagrophytes as the causative agent in this case of tinea capitis is confirmed by the positive hair perforation test. This test is particularly valuable for differentiating between species of Trichophyton, as it assesses the fungus's ability to penetrate and degrade hair keratin.

 

  • Hair Perforation Test: This diagnostic tool is used to differentiate Trichophyton mentagrophytes from Trichophyton rubrum, as T. mentagrophytes demonstrates the ability to perforate hair, causing surface erosion which gives a wedge-shaped appearance to the hair shaft. This is a key characteristic that helps in identifying the fungal species responsible for the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not typically infect hair, more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Option B. Microsporum audouinii: Causes tinea capitis but does not show a positive result on the hair perforation test.

 

Option D. Microsporum gypseum: Another cause of tinea capitis but also does not typically show a positive hair perforation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tinea capitis, a positive hair perforation test indicative of surface erosion and wedge-shaped appearance of the hair shaft confirms the presence of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This test is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatophytes, specifically Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

questions.text: Sequence of Rigor Mortis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head to foot

 

Rigor mortis is the postmortem stiffening of muscles due to biochemical changes in the muscle tissues after death. It typically starts within 2 hours after death, beginning with the myocardium (heart muscle). Externally, the sequence begins at the upper eyelids and then follows a top-to-bottom approach throughout the body.

 

The progression of rigor mortis occurs in three stages:

 

  • Developing Stage (First 12 hours): Rigor begins at the upper parts of the body and progresses downwards.
  • Fully Developed Stage (Next 12 hours): Rigor mortis is fully established.
  • Passing Stage (Last 12 hours): Rigor mortis diminishes in the same order, starting from the head and moving downwards, eventually leading to secondary flaccidity.

 

This sequence is known as Nysten's Rule, which describes rigor mortis development from head to foot, with the exact order being eyelids, neck, jaw, face, chest, upper limbs, abdomen, lower limbs, and finally fingers and toes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Centre to periphery: This option incorrectly suggests that rigor mortis progresses from the center of the body outward, which does not align with the actual top-to-bottom sequence of rigor mortis development.

 

Option C. Foot to head: This option is incorrect as rigor mortis follows a head-to-foot sequence, not the reverse.

 

Option D. Periphery to centre: This option is incorrect because rigor mortis does not start at the outer parts of the body and move inward; instead, it progresses from the head down towards the feet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis follows a sequence known as Nysten's Rule, developing and passing from head to foot, starting with the upper body and ending with the lower extremities.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever for 5 days and you are suspecting enteric fever. What is the best way to diagnose? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood Cultures

 

Explanation:

 

Enteric fever, commonly known as typhoid fever, is typically caused by the bacteria Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi. The best diagnostic method depends on the stage of the disease.

 

For a patient presenting with fever for 5 days (in the first week of illness), blood cultures are the most reliable diagnostic method. During the first week, the bacteria are most likely to be present in the bloodstream, making blood cultures highly effective for identifying the pathogen.

 

Key points:

 

  • Blood cultures: The best diagnostic method for enteric fever during the first week of illness, as the bacteria are present in the blood.
  • Bone marrow cultures: While they have the highest sensitivity at any stage of the disease, they are more invasive and less commonly performed compared to blood cultures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urine cultures: These are not typically useful in the early stages of enteric fever and are more relevant in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella antigens, but it is less specific and sensitive, especially in the early stages. It also has a higher rate of false positives and is not recommended as the primary diagnostic tool in the first week.

 

Option D. Stool cultures: These can be useful later in the disease when the bacteria are shed in the stool, but they are not the best diagnostic method during the first week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For diagnosing enteric fever in the first week of illness, blood cultures are the most effective and reliable method.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Salmonella

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests acute osteomyelitis, and joint aspirate analysis is likely to reveal Salmonella as the causative pathogen.
  • The peripheral smear findings are indicative of sickle cell anemia, a hematological disorder characterized by a variety of complications such as acute painful episodes, priapism, stroke, leg ulcers, and acute chest syndrome (presenting as pneumonia-like symptoms with fever, cough, and hypoxia).
  • Acute osteomyelitis is an infection that affects the bone and is more commonly observed in children.
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for osteomyelitis, in patients with sickle cell anemia, Salmonella is often the causative agent.
  • Additionally, other bacteria such as Hemophilus influenzae, E. coli, Streptococcus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa can also cause the condition.
  • The infection can spread through the blood (hematogenous route) or through external sources like open fractures, iatrogenic interventions, or from nearby infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus. It is the most common organism to cause acute/subacute/chronic osteomyelitis, post-traumatic and post-surgical osteomyelitis in all age groups. It also causes acute pyogenic infections of spine.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type. Sternoclavicular joint is one of the rare location for hematogenous osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

choices.text: Sertoli cell only syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Benign testicular neoplasm

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Sertoli cell only syndrome:
    • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
    • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
    • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular atrophy: Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.

 

Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm: Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Option D. Orchitis: Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury of the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lachman’s test

 

The image shows the examiner performing a test where the knee is placed in 20 to 30 degrees of flexion and the tibia is pulled anteriorly. This describes the Lachman’s test, which is used to assess the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).

 

  • The Lachman’s test is preferred over the anterior drawer test for diagnosing ACL injuries because it can be performed with the knee in slight flexion, which isolates the ACL and reduces the influence of other structures. A positive Lachman’s test, indicated by increased anterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur, suggests an ACL tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior drawer test: The anterior drawer test is also used to assess ACL injuries but differs from the Lachman’s test in that the knee is flexed at 90 degrees. In the anterior drawer test, the examiner pulls the tibia forward while stabilizing the leg, but this test can be less sensitive than the Lachman’s test in acute injuries.

 

Option C. McMurray’s test: McMurray’s test is used to evaluate meniscal injuries, not ligamentous injuries. It involves flexing the knee and applying rotational forces to check for a meniscal tear. It is done with the knee in 90 degrees of flexion and involves listening for clicking or popping sounds in the meniscus.

 

Option D. Posterior drawer test: The posterior drawer test is used to assess the integrity of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). It is performed with the knee at 90 degrees of flexion, and the examiner pushes the tibia backward. This is not the test being performed in the image, as the tibia is being pulled anteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lachman’s test is the most reliable physical exam maneuver for diagnosing ACL tears, performed with the knee in 20-30 degrees of flexion.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following medications should be adjusted or stopped before the procedure? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stop Enalapril

 

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, should be stopped on the day of surgery because:

 

  • ACE inhibitors can cause refractory hypotension during surgery
  • This hypotension is resistant to fluid therapy and vasopressors
  • It occurs when the medication is taken within hours before surgery
  • The recommendation is to omit ACE inhibitors and ARBs on the morning of surgery


Other Options:

 

Options A & D. Aspirin: If taken in a prophylactic dose of 75 mg, it can be continued on the day of surgery. However, if taken in higher doses (150-300 mg), it increases the risk of surgical bleeding and should be stopped 3 days before surgery.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Beta-blockers are safe to continue as they help maintain stable hemodynamics during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Before surgery, ACE inhibitors like Enalapril should be stopped due to the risk of refractory hypotension, while beta-blockers can be continued, and aspirin should be managed based on its dosage.

 

Hypertensive patients on Antihypertensives 

 

  1. ACE Inhibitors - Omitted on day of surgery. 
  2. Angiotensin receptor blockers - Omitted on day of surgery. 
  3. Diuretics - Continued on the day of surgery. 
  4. Beta Blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. 
  5. Calcium channel blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. 
  6. Centrally acting alpha-2 agonists - Continue on the day of surgery. 

 

ANTICOAGULANTS 

 

  • Aspirin continued on day of surgery 
  • Clopidogrel - stopped 7 days prior to surgery 
  • Warfarin- stopped 5 days prior to surgery 
  • Heparin - stopped 4 hours prior to surgery 
  • LMWH-stopped 12 hours prior to surgery 
  • Ticlopidine - stopped 14 days prior to surgery 
  • BRIDGING DRUG - heparin.

choices.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

 

he most likely correct combination for fluorescein dye visualization is Fluorescein dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter. Fluorescein is a yellow dye that, when applied to the eye, emits a bright green fluorescence when illuminated with blue light from a cobalt blue filter. It's commonly used in ophthalmology to detect corneal abrasions, ulcers, or foreign bodies and to assess contact lens fit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a green filter: Lissamine Green is a dye that stains devitalized cells and mucous filaments and is used to visualize damage to the conjunctiva and cornea, particularly in dry eye syndrome. It is typically observed under white light, not a green filter, so this combination is not standard.

 

Option C. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a cobalt blue filter: This is not the standard practice for visualizing Lissamine Green dye. This dye is usually observed under white light, as the cobalt blue filter is specifically used to excite fluorescence from fluorescein dye.

 

Option D. Fluorescein dye - visualized under a green filter: Fluorescein dye is usually visualized under a blue light, not a green filter. When fluorescein is viewed under a green filter, the fluorescence is typically not visible because the green filter would block the green fluorescence emitted by the fluorescein dye.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In ophthalmology, different dyes and filters are used to aid in the diagnosis of various conditions. Fluorescein dye is visualized using a cobalt blue filter, which causes it to fluoresce and highlights areas of corneal compromise. It is crucial to use the appropriate filter for each dye to accurately diagnose and assess ocular surface disorders.

questions.text: The given instrument is used for: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Low air velocity

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Kata thermometer. The Kata thermometer was traditionally used to measure the cooling power of air. This measurement is based on how quickly the thermometer cools down when exposed to moving air, which directly correlates to the cooling effect of the air. However, its modern application is primarily focused on assessing low air velocity. It measures the rate of heat loss in still air, helping to determine the movement and speed of low-velocity air in environments such as controlled climates or specific laboratory conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Air pollution: The Kata thermometer is not used to measure air pollution. Air pollution measurement typically involves devices that can detect particulate matter or specific pollutants, such as gas analyzers or particle counters.

 

Option B. Air humidity: Measuring air humidity is generally done using hygrometer. Hygrometers determine the amount of moisture in the air, which is unrelated to the cooling effect or air velocity measurement.

 

Option C. Cooling power of air: Although historically correct, this option is no longer the primary use of the Kata thermometer. The instrument was used in the past for this purpose, but it has evolved to mainly assess low air velocity, making this answer outdated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kata thermometer is primarily used today to assess low air velocity.

questions.text: Which vaccine is not safe in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Varicella

 

Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine is a live vaccine that is contraindicated during pregnancy. Live vaccines are generally avoided during pregnancy due to the theoretical risk of transmitting the attenuated virus to the fetus, which could potentially cause infection and teratogenicity. The only exception to this rule is the yellow fever vaccine, which may be given if travel to an endemic area is absolutely necessary.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Influenza: Incorrect. While influenza vaccine is available in both live and inactivated forms, the inactivated influenza vaccine is commonly used and is safe during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Rabies: Incorrect. Rabies vaccine is a killed vaccine and is safe to administer during pregnancy if indicated.

 

Option D. Td: Incorrect. Tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine is routinely recommended and safely administered during pregnancy to prevent maternal and neonatal tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All live vaccines except yellow fever are contra-indicated due to the theoretical risk of fetal infection and teratogenicity

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. On further evaluation, the beta- hCG levels were persistently elevated and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the appropriate management in this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate with folinic acid

 

Explanation:

 

Methotrexate with folinic acid: This is a clear case of post-molar choriocarcinoma with lung metastases. Treatment is based on prognostication and staging. According to the given scoring system, the parameters such as the time interval since the antecedent pregnancy, beta-hCG levels, and the presence of lung metastases suggest a low-risk choriocarcinoma. For low-risk choriocarcinoma, the recommended treatment is multi-dose single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate. Methotrexate is administered in a multi-dose regimen (Day 1, 3, 5, 7) alternating with folinic acid (Day 2, 4, 6, 8).

 

 

  • < 6: LOW RISK
  • > 7 HIGH RISK

 

Other options:
