Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate alone might be considered for very low-risk cases. However, in this case, with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels and lung metastases, a multi-dose regimen along with folinic acid is preferred to enhance efficacy and reduce toxicity.

 

Option C. EMACO regimen: The EMACO regimen, which includes etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine, is used for high-risk choriocarcinoma. This patient's score indicates a low-risk profile, making EMACO unnecessary and more toxic than needed.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for choriocarcinoma, especially in the context of low-risk metastatic disease. It may be considered in cases of heavy bleeding or when the disease is confined to the uterus and chemotherapy is not effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low-risk choriocarcinoma post-molar pregnancy with lung metastases is treated with a multi-dose regimen of methotrexate alternating with folinic acid

 

Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

 

The best advice for the exposed students is to receive antibiotic prophylaxis. This is recommended for close contacts of a person with meningococcal meningitis, such as household members, intimate contacts, and anyone who has had direct contact with the patient's oral secretions. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible after exposure and can be effective in preventing secondary cases of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Two doses of polysaccharide vaccine: While vaccination is important, it takes time to provide protection. Therefore, it is not the best option for immediate protection in this situation.

 

Option C. Two doses of conjugate vaccine: The conjugate vaccine is recommended for adolescents and children, but similar to the polysaccharide vaccine, it does not provide immediate protection. Antibiotic prophylaxis is still necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Option D. Single dose of meningococcal vaccine: Again, vaccination alone is not sufficient for immediate protection, and antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

choices.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes
Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
Data insufficient to establish causal association
The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

 

Green tea consumption decreases the risk of DM

 

Relative risk <1 implies negative/inverse association, i.e., risk factor is rather protective for the disease.

 

The risk ratio of 0.84 indicates that the incidence of diabetes mellitus is lower in the group of drinkers of green tea compared to the group of non-drinkers. Therefore, it can be concluded that green tea decreases the risk of diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

questions.text: A patient presented with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor aspect of the forearm. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as follicular hyperkeratosis, is a skin condition commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by the presence of keratotic papules, especially on extensor surfaces such as the forearms, thighs, and buttocks. The deficiency leads to abnormal keratinization of hair follicles, resulting in rough, bumpy skin, primarily affecting areas that are prone to friction or pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Darier’s disease: Darier’s disease is a genetic disorder characterized by wart-like blemishes on the body, particularly in seborrheic areas such as the scalp, forehead, chest, and back. It involves keratinization defects and does not specifically present with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor forearms.

 

Option C. Eruptive xanthoma: Eruptive xanthomas are yellowish papules associated with hyperlipidemia and usually occur on the buttocks, elbows, and knees. They are due to lipid deposits in the skin and do not involve follicular hyperkeratosis or specifically present on the extensor surfaces of the forearms.

 

Option D. Folliculitis: Folliculitis is an infection of the hair follicles, often presenting with small, red or pus-filled bumps. It is generally caused by bacterial infection and does not present as hyperkeratosis related to nutritional deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is linked to vitamin A deficiency and presents as follicular hyperkeratosis, particularly on extensor surfaces like the forearm.

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal airway

 

The instrument shown in the image is a nasopharyngeal airway (NPA). This is a flexible, soft tube that is inserted through the nostril into the nasopharynx to secure an open airway. NPAs are particularly useful in situations where the patient is conscious or semi-conscious and may not tolerate an oropharyngeal airway due to a gag reflex. It is also useful when the oral route is not accessible or practical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oropharyngeal airway:

 

 

Option B. Ovassapian airway:  The Ovassapian airway is a specific type of oropharyngeal airway designed for fiberoptic intubation.

 

 

Option D. Uncuffed endotracheal tube

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nasopharyngeal airway (NPA) is a flexible tube used to secure an airway via the nasal passage, especially in patients who are semi-conscious and have an intact gag reflex.

questions.text: Identify the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bier’s block

 

The image depicts the setup for a Bier’s block, also known as intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA).

 

This technique is commonly used for short surgical procedures on the extremities, such as the hands or forearms.

 

The process involves placing a double cuff tourniquet on the limb to occlude blood flow, then injecting a local anesthetic (such as lidocaine) into a vein in the isolated limb.

 

The tourniquet prevents the anesthetic from circulating out of the limb, thus providing anesthesia to the area. Bier's block is a fast and effective method for producing anesthesia in a limb without the need for general anesthesia or nerve blocks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve block: A radial nerve block involves injecting anesthetic near the radial nerve . It does not involve a tourniquet or intravenous injection of local anesthetic as depicted in the image.

 

Option B. Axillary block: An axillary block is a type of brachial plexus block where anesthetic is injected near the axillary artery to block the nerves supplying the upper limb.

 

Option D. Wrist block: A wrist block involves injecting local anesthetic near the nerves at the wrist to provide anesthesia to the hand. It is different from Bier's block and does not involve a tourniquet or intravenous injection as shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bier’s block, or intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA), is used for anesthetizing a limb by injecting local anesthetic into a vein while using a tourniquet to confine the anesthetic to the limb.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best antibiotic choice for a patient with otitis media who is allergic to penicillins? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Explanation: 

 

For patients with penicillin allergy, azithromycin is the best choice because:

 

  • It doesn't belong to β-lactam family, so no cross-allergenicity
  • Can be administered orally unlike amikacin which needs injection
  • Effective against gram-positive bacteria which commonly cause otitis media

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone: Incorrect

 

  • It's a cephalosporin which belongs to β-lactam family
  • Contraindicated in patients with penicillin allergy due to cross-allergenicity

 

Option C. Amikacin: Incorrect

 

  • Although amikacin is safe in penicillin-allergic patients, it is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria, while otitis media is commonly caused by gram-positive organisms. 

 

Option D. Meropenem: Incorrect

 

  • It's a carbapenem which belongs to β-lactam family
  • Contraindicated in penicillin allergy due to cross-allergenicity

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In penicillin-allergic patients, β-lactam antibiotics (penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems) are contraindicated due to cross-allergenicity. Azithromycin is a safe and effective alternative.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with severe abdominal distension, pain, and absolute constipation for the past two days. Physical examination reveals a distended, tympanic abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sigmoid volvulus

 

Explanation: 


The case presents classical features of sigmoid volvulus, which is confirmed by the radiological findings showing:

 

  • Classic "coffee bean" sign - two dilated bowel loops without haustra
  • Common in elderly patients
  • Presents with severe abdominal distension and constipation The diagnosis is supported by typical patient demographics (elderly) and clinical presentation (constipation, distension). Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus, particularly in older patients with chronic constipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small bowel volvulus: Shows different radiological pattern with "step ladder" appearance of dilated small bowel loops. Small bowel shows complete mucosal folds (valvulae connivence’s), unlike the pattern seen here.

 

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: While present here, this is a general term. The specific type (sigmoid volvulus) can be identified by the characteristic radiological appearance. Small bowel obstruction shows complete mucosal folds, while large bowel obstruction shows haustra.

 

Option D. Caecal volvulus: Shows a single dilated loop with haustral pattern forming a "C" sign, unlike the double-loop "coffee bean" appearance seen in sigmoid volvulus. Cecal volvulus is less common than sigmoid volvulus.

 

 

Educational Objective: 


Sigmoid volvulus presents with the characteristic "coffee bean" sign on X-ray (two dilated loops without haustra) and typically occurs in elderly patients with chronic constipation.



Sigmoid Volvulus vs Cecal Volvulus

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

 

A ranula is a type of mucocele found on the floor of the mouth, associated with the sublingual gland. During the surgical excision of a ranula along with the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is at risk of being injured. The lingual nerve runs close to the sublingual gland and is responsible for sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Due to its proximity, it is the structure most likely to be damaged during such surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mylohyoid muscle: The mylohyoid muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is situated below the sublingual gland. It is less likely to be injured during the excision of a ranula as the procedure primarily involves the tissues above this muscle.

 

Option C. Submental artery: The submental artery supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the mylohyoid muscle. While it is in the general area, it is not as closely associated with the sublingual gland as the lingual nerve is, making it less likely to be injured during this specific procedure.

 

Option D. Sublingual artery: The sublingual artery supplies blood to the sublingual gland and the surrounding tissues. Although it is close to the surgical site, the risk of injury to the lingual nerve is higher due to its course and proximity to the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.
